description.level3: Pieces of old viruses that got stuck in our DNA long ago.
description.level4: DNA from viruses that infected our ancestors millions of years ago and became part of our genome.
description.level5: Remnants of retroviruses that inserted themselves into our ancestors' DNA millions of years ago.
description.level6: Human Endogenous Retroviruses (HERVs) are viral sequences integrated into our genome through ancient infections.
description.level7: HERVs are retroviral sequences that integrated into the germline of ancestral primates and were inherited vertically.
description.level8: Human Endogenous Retroviruses represent ~8% of the genome, derived from exogenous retroviral infections that integrated into germline cells.

description.level3: Bits of DNA that can copy themselves and move to new spots.
description.level4: DNA sequences that can make copies of themselves and jump to different places in your genome.
description.level5: Long stretches of DNA that can duplicate themselves and insert the copy elsewhere in the genome.
description.level6: Long Interspersed Nuclear Elements (LINEs) are autonomous retrotransposons capable of self-replication.
description.level7: LINEs are class I transposable elements that replicate through an RNA intermediate using reverse transcriptase.
description.level8: LINE elements, particularly LINE-1, are autonomous non-LTR retrotransposons constituting ~17% of the human genome with ongoing activity.

description.level3: Tiny pieces of DNA that copied themselves over a million times!
description.level4: Small bits of DNA that have duplicated themselves over and over, appearing more than a million times.
description.level5: Short DNA sequences that have proliferated to over a million copies throughout the human genome.
description.level6: SINEs (Short Interspersed Nuclear Elements) like Alu are non-autonomous elements that hijack LINE machinery to copy themselves.
description.level7: Alu elements are primate-specific SINEs that depend on LINE-1 proteins for retrotransposition, numbering over 1 million copies.
description.level8: Alu elements are ~300bp non-autonomous retrotransposons comprising ~11% of the genome, retrotranspositionally active via LINE-1 machinery.

description.level3: Broken copies of genes that don't work anymore, like fossils in your DNA.
description.level4: Old copies of genes that have broken down over time and no longer make proteins.
description.level5: Non-functional copies of genes that accumulated mutations and can no longer produce working proteins.
description.level6: Pseudogenes are defunct relatives of functional genes that have lost their protein-coding ability through mutations.
description.level7: Pseudogenes arise through duplication or retrotransposition and accumulate disabling mutations while preserving sequence similarity to parent genes.
description.level8: Pseudogenes are genomic sequences with homology to functional genes but rendered non-functional by frameshift mutations, premature stops, or regulatory defects.

description.level3: DNA pieces that used to be able to cut themselves out and paste somewhere else.
description.level4: Ancient DNA sequences that could move around by cutting themselves out and inserting elsewhere.
description.level5: DNA transposons that historically moved via a cut-and-paste mechanism, though most are now inactive.
description.level6: DNA transposons are Class II transposable elements that mobilized via transposase-mediated excision and reinsertion.
description.level7: DNA transposons moved through a conservative cut-and-paste mechanism, unlike retrotransposons' replicative copy-and-paste method.
description.level8: DNA transposons constitute ~3% of the genome, mobilizing via transposase enzymes, though all human copies became inactive ~37 MYA.

description.level3: Copies of mitochondria DNA that jumped into your main chromosomes!
description.level4: Ancient pieces of mitochondrial DNA that escaped and inserted into your nuclear chromosomes.
description.level5: Nuclear copies of mitochondrial DNA sequences that transferred from mitochondria to nuclear chromosomes.
description.level6: NUMTs (Nuclear Mitochondrial DNA segments) are mitochondrial sequences integrated into nuclear chromosomes.
description.level7: NUMTs represent ongoing DNA transfer from mitochondria to nucleus, with ~750 insertions totaling ~600kb in the human genome.
description.level8: Nuclear mitochondrial DNA transfers (NUMTs) provide a molecular fossil record of mitochondrial evolution and can complicate forensic/medical mtDNA analysis.

description.level3: Special parts of DNA that changed super fast only in humans - maybe what makes us unique!
description.level4: DNA regions that stayed the same in animals for millions of years but changed rapidly in humans.
description.level5: Genomic regions highly conserved across mammals but showing accelerated evolution specifically in humans.
description.level6: Human Accelerated Regions (HARs) show significant nucleotide substitutions in humans despite deep conservation across vertebrates.
description.level7: HARs represent sequences under strong purifying selection for >300 million years that experienced positive selection in the human lineage.
description.level8: Human Accelerated Regions exhibit statistically significant human-specific substitution rates, often in non-coding regulatory regions near neurodevelopmental genes.

description.level3: DNA we got from Neanderthals when humans and Neanderthals had kids together long ago!
description.level4: Pieces of Neanderthal DNA that entered human genomes when our ancestors met and had children with Neanderthals.
description.level5: Genomic regions inherited from Neanderthals through interbreeding ~50,000-60,000 years ago.
description.level6: Neanderthal introgression regions represent archaic hominin DNA acquired through hybridization events in Eurasia.
description.level7: Introgressed Neanderthal haplotypes comprise ~2% of non-African genomes, with some regions showing adaptive significance.
description.level8: Neanderthal-derived sequences show complex patterns of selection, with some haplotypes under positive selection (immune genes) and others depleted (hybrid incompatibility).

description.level3: Huge stretches of DNA with no genes at all - like empty deserts in your genome!
description.level4: Very large regions of DNA that contain no protein-coding genes - we're not sure why they exist.
description.level5: Extended genomic regions spanning millions of bases that lack any protein-coding genes.
description.level6: Gene deserts are megabase-scale regions devoid of protein-coding genes, often containing important regulatory elements.
description.level7: Gene deserts may harbor long-range enhancers, conserved non-coding elements, or represent evolutionary remnants.
description.level8: Gene deserts often contain crucial cis-regulatory elements controlling distant developmental genes, explaining their evolutionary conservation despite lacking coding sequences.

description.level3: DNA we got from Denisovans - mysterious ancient humans we know mostly from their DNA!
description.level4: Pieces of Denisovan DNA that entered human genomes through ancient interbreeding.
description.level5: Genomic regions inherited from Denisovans, a sister group to Neanderthals known mainly from genetics.
description.level6: Denisovan introgression regions represent archaic hominin DNA from a population identified in 2010.
description.level7: Denisovan DNA comprises up to 6% of some Oceanian genomes, with evidence for multiple introgression events.
description.level8: Denisovan introgression shows complex geographic distribution, with highest levels in Melanesia and distinct contributions in different populations.

description.level3: DNA from ancient human relatives like Neanderthals and Denisovans!
description.level4: Genetic material inherited from multiple ancient human species that bred with our ancestors.
description.level5: Genomic regions showing signatures of introgression from multiple archaic human populations.
description.level6: Archaic introgression from both Neanderthal and Denisovan sources, sometimes overlapping.
description.level7: Some genomic regions show introgression from multiple archaic sources with complex selection histories.
description.level8: Archaic DNA mapping reveals complex admixture history with multiple hominin lineages contributing to modern human genetic variation.

description.level3: Places where old chromosomes stuck together to make new ones!
description.level4: Sites where ancestral chromosomes fused together during human evolution.
description.level5: Chromosomal fusion sites that explain why humans have 46 chromosomes while apes have 48.
description.level6: Telomere-to-telomere fusion events that restructured the human karyotype during evolution.
description.level7: Chromosomal fusion sites contain diagnostic signatures like interstitial telomeres and vestigial centromeres.
description.level8: Chromosomal fusions represent major karyotypic changes with retained molecular signatures serving as evolutionary landmarks.

description.level3: Genes that can cause diseases when they don't work right.
description.level4: Important genes that cause known genetic diseases when mutated.
description.level5: Genes with well-established roles in human genetic disorders, from rare to common diseases.
description.level6: Disease-associated genes with clinical significance for diagnosis, prognosis, or treatment.
description.level7: Genes with pathogenic variants causing Mendelian disorders or significantly modifying complex disease risk.
description.level8: Clinically actionable genes with established genotype-phenotype correlations and evidence-based management guidelines.

description.level3: Things in DNA that only humans have - not chimps, gorillas, or any other animal!
description.level4: Genetic features unique to humans that evolved after we split from other apes.
description.level5: Genomic elements unique to humans, including duplications, deletions, and accelerated regions.
description.level6: Human-specific genetic changes including gene duplications, losses, and regulatory modifications.
description.level7: Human lineage-specific genomic features arising since the human-chimpanzee divergence ~6-7 MYA.
description.level8: Human-specific genomic changes encompass structural variants, accelerated sequences, and novel genes arising through various mutational mechanisms.

description.level3: Gene regions that might help some people live extra long lives!
description.level4: Genes associated with living to very old ages, found by studying centenarians.
description.level5: Genomic regions containing variants associated with exceptional longevity and healthy aging.
description.level6: Longevity-associated loci identified through centenarian studies and aging research.
description.level7: Genes with replicated associations to exceptional longevity, often involved in stress response and metabolism.
description.level8: Validated longevity loci with mechanistic links to conserved aging pathways including insulin/IGF-1, mTOR, and sirtuins.

shortDescription.level3: An old virus gene that helps babies grow inside their moms!
shortDescription.level4: A gene from an ancient virus that now helps connect babies to their mothers during pregnancy.
shortDescription.level5: A former viral gene that evolved to help form the placenta, connecting mother and baby.
shortDescription.level6: An endogenous retroviral envelope gene co-opted for placental syncytiotrophoblast fusion.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-W derived Syncytin-1 mediates cell-cell fusion in placental development, demonstrating viral domestication.
shortDescription.level8: Syncytin-1 (ERVW-1) is a fusogenic envelope protein derived from HERV-W, essential for syncytiotrophoblast formation.

funFact.level3: Without this old virus, mammals might not be able to have babies the way we do!
funFact.level4: This virus DNA was captured about 25 million years ago and became essential for pregnancy!
funFact.level5: We essentially repurposed a virus infection to help with pregnancy - talk about making lemonade from lemons!
funFact.level6: Syncytin-1 demonstrates exaptation: a viral gene repurposed for essential host function.
funFact.level7: Multiple mammals independently captured different retroviral envelopes for placentation - convergent evolution at its finest.
funFact.level8: Syncytins represent one of the clearest examples of retroviral domestication across mammalian evolution.

shortDescription.level3: Another virus gene that helps with having babies.
shortDescription.level4: A second viral gene that helps protect babies in the womb.
shortDescription.level5: Another domesticated viral gene involved in placental development and immune protection.
shortDescription.level6: A second retroviral envelope gene with immunosuppressive and fusogenic functions in the placenta.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-FRD derived Syncytin-2 has both fusogenic and immunosuppressive properties for fetomaternal tolerance.
shortDescription.level8: Syncytin-2 (ERVFRD-1) provides both cell fusion capability and immunomodulatory function at the maternal-fetal interface.

features.name: HERV-K (HML-2)

shortDescription.level3: The most recent virus that got stuck in human DNA - only about 200,000 years ago!
shortDescription.level4: The newest virus DNA in humans, inserted around the time modern humans appeared.
shortDescription.level5: The most recently active human endogenous retrovirus, with some copies still potentially active.
shortDescription.level6: HERV-K HML-2 represents the youngest HERV family with human-specific insertions and residual coding capacity.
shortDescription.level7: HERV-K (HML-2) is the only HERV family with human-specific members, some retaining open reading frames.
shortDescription.level8: HERV-K HML-2 elements include human-specific proviruses with intact ORFs, suggesting recent (<1MYA) and possibly ongoing activity.

funFact.level3: Some scientists think this virus might still be able to wake up!
funFact.level4: This is so young (for virus DNA) that different people have different copies!
funFact.level5: HERV-K is polymorphic - meaning some people have copies that others don't!
funFact.level6: Some HERV-K insertions are present in only some humans, indicating very recent integration.
funFact.level7: HERV-K polymorphism and potential somatic activity make it unique among human ERVs.
funFact.level8: HERV-K HML-2 shows human-specific polymorphic insertions and evidence of somatic activity in certain pathological conditions.

features.functionKnown: Unknown, possibly involved in some diseases

features.name: Active LINE-1

shortDescription.level3: A piece of DNA that can still copy itself and move around!
shortDescription.level4: One of about 100 LINE-1 elements that can still actively jump around in your genome.
shortDescription.level5: An active retrotransposon that continues to make new copies of itself in human cells.
shortDescription.level6: A full-length, retrotranspositionally competent LINE-1 element with intact ORFs.
shortDescription.level7: Active L1HS elements retain functional ORF1p and ORF2p for autonomous retrotransposition.
shortDescription.level8: This full-length L1HS element (~6kb) contains intact ORF1 (RNA chaperone) and ORF2 (RT/EN) for autonomous mobilization.

funFact.level3: These jumping genes are still making new copies in your cells right now!
funFact.level4: Out of 500,000 LINE-1 copies, only about 100 can still jump - but they do!
funFact.level5: LINE-1 elements cause about 1 in every 250 disease-causing mutations in humans.
funFact.level6: Active LINE-1s contribute to somatic mosaicism and can cause insertional mutagenesis.
funFact.level7: L1 retrotransposition generates ~80-100 novel insertions per individual per generation.
funFact.level8: Active L1 elements drive ongoing genomic evolution, contributing to structural variation and disease mutations.

features.functionKnown: Creates genomic diversity, sometimes causes disease

shortDescription.level3: A jumping gene that landed in the wrong spot and causes a blood disease.
shortDescription.level4: A LINE-1 that jumped into an important gene and caused the first known disease from a jumping gene.
shortDescription.level5: The first documented case of a transposon insertion causing human disease - hemophilia A.
shortDescription.level6: A LINE-1 insertion in the Factor VIII gene, the first identified retrotransposon-mediated human disease.
shortDescription.level7: This L1 insertion in F8 intron 14 was the first demonstration of L1 retrotransposition causing human genetic disease.
shortDescription.level8: The F8 L1 insertion (1988) established L1 as an active mutagen, disrupting Factor VIII expression and causing hemophilia A.

features.name: BRCA1 Alu Cluster

shortDescription.level3: A bunch of copied DNA bits that sometimes cause mix-ups in an important cancer gene.
shortDescription.level4: Many Alu copies clustered together that can cause errors when DNA is copied.
shortDescription.level5: A region dense with Alu elements that promotes harmful recombination in the BRCA1 gene.
shortDescription.level6: An Alu-rich region in BRCA1 that facilitates pathogenic Alu-mediated deletions and duplications.
shortDescription.level7: The high Alu density in BRCA1 (~40% of gene) predisposes to non-allelic homologous recombination events.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1's exceptionally high Alu content drives Alu-Alu mediated rearrangements, accounting for ~10% of pathogenic variants.

features.functionKnown: Causes genomic instability, contributes to BRCA1 mutations

shortDescription.level3: A copy-paste gene piece that's active in brain cells.
shortDescription.level4: An Alu element that can still jump around, especially in brain cells.
shortDescription.level5: An active Alu element that retrotransposes in neural progenitor cells, contributing to brain diversity.
shortDescription.level6: Alu elements show increased retrotransposition in neural progenitors, creating somatic mosaicism.
shortDescription.level7: L1/Alu activity in neural progenitor cells generates somatic insertions contributing to neuronal diversity.
shortDescription.level8: Somatic retrotransposition of Alu elements in NPCs contributes to neuronal genome mosaicism and potentially neural diversity.

funFact.level3: Your brain cells might each have slightly different DNA because of jumping genes!
funFact.level4: Jumping genes are more active in brain cells, making each neuron slightly unique!
funFact.level5: L1 and Alu activity in the brain means your neurons aren't all genetically identical.
funFact.level6: Somatic retrotransposition creates neuronal mosaicism - each brain cell may have unique insertions.
funFact.level7: Neural retrotransposition may contribute to neural circuit diversity and plasticity.
funFact.level8: Elevated L1/Alu somatic activity in neurons may contribute to neural diversity, though functional significance remains debated.

shortDescription.level3: Old smell genes that stopped working when our ancestors started using their eyes more.
shortDescription.level4: Broken copies of smell genes - we lost many when vision became more important.
shortDescription.level5: A cluster of non-functional olfactory receptor genes, remnants of our more smell-dependent ancestors.
shortDescription.level6: Olfactory receptor pseudogenes representing the decline of smell as humans evolved better color vision.
shortDescription.level7: The OR gene family shows massive pseudogenization (~60%) correlating with the evolution of trichromatic vision.
shortDescription.level8: Human olfactory receptor pseudogenes reflect relaxed selection following trichromacy acquisition and olfaction's reduced fitness contribution.

funFact.level3: Dogs have way fewer broken smell genes, which is why their noses are so much better!
funFact.level4: We have about 400 working smell genes but over 600 broken ones!
funFact.level5: Humans have ~400 functional OR genes but ~600 pseudogenes - dogs have far fewer pseudogenes!
funFact.level6: The human OR repertoire is ~40% functional vs ~80% in dogs, reflecting our visual vs olfactory lifestyle.
funFact.level7: OR pseudogenization accelerated in the catarrhine lineage coincident with full trichromacy evolution.
funFact.level8: Comparative genomics reveals OR pseudogenization rates correlate inversely with olfactory dependence across mammals.

shortDescription.level3: A broken gene that means humans can't make their own Vitamin C!
shortDescription.level4: The reason we need to eat fruits and vegetables - this gene broke millions of years ago.
shortDescription.level5: A non-functional vitamin C synthesis gene, explaining why humans require dietary vitamin C.
shortDescription.level6: GULOP pseudogene lost function ~40 MYA, making vitamin C an essential dietary nutrient for primates.
shortDescription.level7: The GULO pseudogene contains multiple disabling mutations shared with other simian primates.
shortDescription.level8: GULOP (L-gulonolactone oxidase pseudogene) carries shared-derived mutations establishing vitamin C auxotrophy in Haplorrhini.

funFact.level3: Most animals make their own Vitamin C, but we have to eat it because this gene broke!
funFact.level4: Sailors used to get sick (scurvy) because they didn't know they needed vitamin C - blame this gene!
funFact.level5: This broken gene is why scurvy plagued sailors - we can't synthesize vitamin C like most mammals.
funFact.level6: Guinea pigs independently broke their GULO gene, making them useful scurvy research models.
funFact.level7: GULO pseudogenization occurred independently in guinea pigs, some bats, and passerine birds.
funFact.level8: Multiple independent GULO losses across mammals demonstrate parallel evolution under fruit-rich dietary conditions.

shortDescription.level3: Broken egg-making genes from when our ancient ancestors laid eggs!
shortDescription.level4: Leftover genes from egg-laying ancestors - proof that mammals evolved from egg-layers.
shortDescription.level5: Remnants of vitellogenin genes used by our egg-laying ancestors, replaced by lactation.
shortDescription.level6: Vitellogenin pseudogenes trace mammalian evolution from oviparity to viviparity and lactation.
shortDescription.level7: VIT pseudogenization correlates temporally with casein gene expansion during lactation evolution.
shortDescription.level8: Human vitellogenin pseudogenes show stepwise inactivation coinciding with casein gene family expansion ~100-300 MYA.

funFact.level3: We still have broken egg genes because we evolved from animals that laid eggs!
funFact.level4: When mammals evolved to make milk, we didn't need egg yolk genes anymore - but they're still there, broken!
funFact.level5: The vitellogenin genes broke as casein (milk protein) genes evolved - we traded eggs for milk!
funFact.level6: Vitellogenin loss and casein emergence show clear evolutionary tradeoff timing.
funFact.level7: The VIT/casein evolutionary transition is a textbook example of gene family replacement.
funFact.level8: VIT pseudogenization dates align with casein gene family radiation, demonstrating molecular basis for oviparity-viviparity transition.

shortDescription.level3: An ancient jumping gene that stopped jumping millions of years ago.
shortDescription.level4: A cut-and-paste gene that was active in our distant ancestors but is now a DNA fossil.
shortDescription.level5: A DNA transposon that was active in early mammals but became immobile ~37 million years ago.
shortDescription.level6: A hAT-superfamily DNA transposon, part of the Charlie/MER family inactive since ~37 MYA.
shortDescription.level7: Charlie elements are non-autonomous hAT derivatives that mobilized via ancestral autonomous copies.
shortDescription.level8: Charlie family elements represent MITEs derived from hAT-family transposons, with activity ceasing in the primate lineage.

shortDescription.level3: A virus gene that became super important for making memories!
shortDescription.level4: An ancient virus gene that your brain uses to form and store memories.
shortDescription.level5: A gene derived from a retrotransposon that's essential for memory formation in the brain.
shortDescription.level6: Arc encodes a Gag-like protein that forms capsid-like structures for intercellular mRNA transport.
shortDescription.level7: Arc protein assembles into virus-like capsids that transfer mRNA between neurons for synaptic plasticity.
shortDescription.level8: Arc represents an exapted Ty3/Gypsy Gag protein that forms capsid-like particles mediating intercellular mRNA transfer at synapses.

funFact.level3: This virus gene helps your brain cells talk to each other to make memories!
funFact.level4: Arc protein actually makes little virus-like shells to send messages between brain cells!
funFact.level5: Arc makes capsid-like structures (like virus shells) to transport RNA between neurons!
funFact.level6: Arc represents a striking example of viral gene domestication for neural function.
funFact.level7: Arc's virus-like mRNA delivery mechanism suggests retroviral exaptation for neural circuit function.
funFact.level8: Arc exemplifies molecular domestication where Gag's capsid-forming ability was repurposed for synaptic plasticity.

shortDescription.level3: A muscle gene that broke, letting our heads get bigger for bigger brains!
shortDescription.level4: A jaw muscle gene that stopped working, possibly letting human skulls grow larger.
shortDescription.level5: A myosin gene inactivated ~2.4 MYA, coinciding with brain expansion in human evolution.
shortDescription.level6: MYH16 pseudogenization may have relaxed constraints on skull size, facilitating encephalization.
shortDescription.level7: The MYH16 inactivating mutation (~2.4 MYA) correlates with reduced masticatory musculature and cranial expansion.
shortDescription.level8: MYH16 carries a 2-bp deletion creating a frameshift, dated to ~2.4 MYA coincident with Homo brain expansion.

funFact.level3: Some scientists think breaking this gene helped humans grow bigger brains!
funFact.level4: Weaker jaw muscles might have let our skulls grow bigger to fit larger brains!
funFact.level5: The timing of this gene breaking matches perfectly with when human brains started getting bigger!
funFact.level6: This hypothesis links masticatory muscle reduction to relaxed cranial constraint.
funFact.level7: While correlation is striking, causation between MYH16 loss and encephalization remains debated.
funFact.level8: The MYH16-encephalization hypothesis remains controversial, though temporal correlation is notable.

shortDescription.level3: Special markers that help turn off one X chromosome in girls.
shortDescription.level4: LINE elements that help silence one X chromosome in females, so they don't have double the genes.
shortDescription.level5: LINE-1 elements enriched on the X chromosome that may facilitate X-inactivation spreading.
shortDescription.level6: X-chromosome LINE density correlates with X-inactivation efficiency, possibly serving as way stations.
shortDescription.level7: Lyon's 'way station' hypothesis suggests LINEs propagate heterochromatin during X-inactivation.
shortDescription.level8: X-chromosome L1 enrichment (~30% vs ~17% autosomal) may facilitate XIST-mediated silencing propagation.

funFact.level3: Girls have two X chromosomes but only use one - these DNA bits help pick which one!
funFact.level4: The X chromosome has almost twice as many LINE elements as other chromosomes!
funFact.level5: The X chromosome is 30% LINEs (vs 17% elsewhere) - this may help with X-inactivation!
funFact.level6: The 2-fold LINE enrichment on X chromosomes is a striking genomic feature with functional implications.
funFact.level7: X-linked LINE enrichment is conserved across mammals, supporting functional significance.
funFact.level8: Lyon's way-station hypothesis for LINE-mediated X-inactivation spreading remains supported by genomic and functional data.

shortDescription.level3: Old virus bits that help train our immune system!
shortDescription.level4: HERV sequences that evolved to help regulate how our immune system works.
shortDescription.level5: Endogenous retroviruses co-opted for interferon response and immune regulation.
shortDescription.level6: Multiple HERV-derived sequences serve as interferon-stimulated enhancers and immune regulators.
shortDescription.level7: ERV-derived sequences constitute a significant fraction of primate-specific interferon response elements.
shortDescription.level8: HERV LTRs provide species-specific cis-regulatory elements for innate immunity genes, particularly in interferon pathways.

funFact.level3: These old viruses now help us fight new viruses - they switched sides!
funFact.level4: Ancient viruses that once tried to infect us now help our immune system fight other infections!
funFact.level5: ERVs contribute many regulatory elements to our immune response - former enemies turned allies!
funFact.level6: About 20% of human interferon response elements derive from endogenous retroviruses.
funFact.level7: ERV-derived regulatory elements show species-specific immune response patterns.
funFact.level8: ERV domestication for innate immunity represents ongoing host-virus co-evolution with functional consequences.

shortDescription.level3: Broken taste genes that used to help us detect more bitter things.
shortDescription.level4: Non-working bitter taste receptor genes, showing we've lost some taste sensitivity.
shortDescription.level5: Pseudogenized bitter taste receptors reflecting dietary changes in human evolution.
shortDescription.level6: TAS2R pseudogenes represent relaxed selection on bitter detection as diet shifted.
shortDescription.level7: Human TAS2R pseudogenization varies by population, reflecting local dietary adaptation.
shortDescription.level8: TAS2R pseudogene variation shows population-specific patterns correlating with historical dietary toxin exposure.

funFact.level3: Different people have different broken taste genes, so we all taste things a bit differently!
funFact.level4: Some bitter taste genes are broken in some people but not others - that's why we like different foods!
funFact.level5: TAS2R gene variation explains why some people hate Brussels sprouts while others love them!
funFact.level6: TAS2R variation contributes to individual differences in bitter food preferences.
funFact.level7: Population-specific TAS2R pseudogenization patterns reflect local dietary selective pressures.
funFact.level8: TAS2R copy number and pseudogenization variation represents ongoing neutral evolution and dietary adaptation.

shortDescription.level3: Special repeating DNA that holds chromosomes together when cells divide.
shortDescription.level4: Highly repetitive DNA at chromosome centers essential for cell division.
shortDescription.level5: Alpha satellite DNA at centromeres that enables proper chromosome segregation during cell division.
shortDescription.level6: Centromeric alpha satellite arrays provide the foundation for kinetochore assembly.
shortDescription.level7: Alpha satellite higher-order repeats (HORs) establish centromere identity through CENP-A nucleosome positioning.
shortDescription.level8: Alpha satellite HOR arrays are essential for centromere function, kinetochore assembly, and accurate chromosome segregation.

funFact.level3: These are the parts that hold your chromosomes in the middle!
funFact.level4: Without this repeating DNA, your chromosomes would get lost when cells divide!
funFact.level5: Centromeric DNA is so repetitive that it was excluded from the 'completed' human genome until 2022!
funFact.level6: The T2T consortium finally sequenced centromeric regions in 2022, completing the human genome.
funFact.level7: Centromeric alpha satellites remained as gaps in GRCh38 until the T2T-CHM13 assembly.
funFact.level8: Complete centromeric sequence assembly required specialized long-read technologies due to repeat complexity.

features.name: Telomeric Repeats

shortDescription.level3: Special caps on the ends of chromosomes, like the plastic tips on shoelaces.
shortDescription.level4: Protective repeating sequences at chromosome ends that prevent DNA damage.
shortDescription.level5: TTAGGG repeats at chromosome ends that protect DNA and shorten with each cell division.
shortDescription.level6: Telomeric repeats protect chromosome ends and shorten progressively, limiting replicative lifespan.
shortDescription.level7: Telomere attrition serves as a mitotic clock; critically short telomeres trigger senescence or apoptosis.
shortDescription.level8: Telomeric (TTAGGG)n arrays protect chromosome termini; progressive shortening underlies replicative senescence and is counteracted by telomerase in stem/cancer cells.

funFact.level3: These get shorter every time your cells divide - they're like a countdown clock!
funFact.level4: Your telomeres shorten as you age, which is why scientists study them in aging research.
funFact.level5: Telomere length is linked to aging - some jellyfish stay young by constantly rebuilding theirs!
funFact.level6: Telomere biology won the 2009 Nobel Prize and is central to cancer and aging research.
funFact.level7: Telomerase reactivation is a hallmark of cancer; telomere maintenance is essential for immortalization.
funFact.level8: Telomere biology bridges replicative senescence, stem cell function, aging, and oncogenesis.

features.functionKnown: Essential for chromosome stability and aging

shortDescription.level3: Alu pieces that let your cells edit messages in your RNA!
shortDescription.level4: Inverted Alu pairs that enable cells to change RNA messages after they're made.
shortDescription.level5: Alu elements in inverted orientation that create RNA structures subject to A-to-I editing.
shortDescription.level6: Inverted Alu pairs form dsRNA structures extensively edited by ADAR enzymes.
shortDescription.level7: Alu-derived dsRNA is the primary substrate for ADAR A-to-I editing in the human transcriptome.
shortDescription.level8: Primate-specific Alu-mediated A-to-I editing shapes the transcriptome and innate immune dsRNA recognition.

funFact.level3: Your cells can change the messages in RNA - Alu elements make this possible!
funFact.level4: More than 100 million spots in your RNA can be edited, mostly thanks to Alu elements!
funFact.level5: Humans have millions of A-to-I RNA editing sites, mostly in Alu - more than any other mammal!
funFact.level6: The human editome contains >100 million A-to-I sites, vastly exceeding other mammals.
funFact.level7: Alu-mediated expansion of the editome may contribute to human-specific neural complexity.
funFact.level8: Massive Alu-dependent editome expansion in primates may contribute to neural transcriptome complexity and cognitive evolution.

shortDescription.level3: An extra backup copy of an important gene that can help if the main one breaks.
shortDescription.level4: A duplicated region containing SMN genes - having backups can protect against disease.
shortDescription.level5: The SMN1/SMN2 duplication where SMN2 copy number modifies spinal muscular atrophy severity.
shortDescription.level6: Segmental duplication created SMN1/SMN2; SMN2 copy number is a key SMA severity modifier.
shortDescription.level7: SMN2's partial functional redundancy with SMN1 underlies SMA pathogenesis and antisense oligo therapy rationale.
shortDescription.level8: The SMN1/SMN2 segmental duplication illustrates how paralog redundancy modifies disease phenotypes and enables novel therapeutic strategies.

funFact.level3: The backup copy (SMN2) is why gene therapy for SMA works!
funFact.level4: Doctors can now use the backup SMN2 gene to help treat spinal muscular atrophy!
funFact.level5: SMN2 copy number varies between people and directly affects SMA disease severity.
funFact.level6: SMN2-targeted therapies (nusinersen, risdiplam) exploit this segmental duplication for treatment.
funFact.level7: The SMN locus exemplifies translational genomics: understanding duplication biology enabled therapy.
funFact.level8: SMN2-directed therapeutics (splice modulators, gene replacement) represent precision medicine enabled by segmental duplication biology.

shortDescription.level3: A piece of your mitochondria's DNA that escaped into your main chromosomes!
shortDescription.level4: Mitochondrial DNA that jumped into chromosome 1 - like a refugee finding a new home.
shortDescription.level5: A ~5kb mitochondrial DNA segment that transferred to nuclear chromosome 1.
shortDescription.level6: A large NUMT representing near-complete mitochondrial genome transfer to chromosome 1.
shortDescription.level7: This NUMT contains multiple mitochondrial gene fragments including portions of ND genes and tRNAs.
shortDescription.level8: This ~5kb NUMT represents a single integration event capturing a substantial mtDNA segment with degraded but recognizable gene sequences.

funFact.level3: Your mitochondria have their own DNA, and sometimes pieces escape!
funFact.level4: This DNA used to be in tiny power stations in your cells, then it moved to a chromosome!
funFact.level5: NUMTs are like molecular fossils showing how mitochondrial DNA transfers to the nucleus over time.
funFact.level6: NUMTs can complicate forensic mtDNA analysis when they're accidentally amplified instead of true mtDNA.
funFact.level7: NUMT insertions provide dated molecular fossils of mtDNA sequence evolution.
funFact.level8: NUMTs serve as paleogenomic records, preserving ancestral mtDNA sequences at their time of integration.

shortDescription.level3: A new piece of mitochondria DNA that just recently jumped into your chromosomes!
shortDescription.level4: A recent mitochondrial DNA transfer - so new that some people have it and others don't!
shortDescription.level5: A polymorphic NUMT present in some human populations but not others, indicating recent integration.
shortDescription.level6: A polymorphic NUMT insertion showing ongoing mitochondrial-to-nuclear DNA transfer in humans.
shortDescription.level7: This NUMT is polymorphic in human populations, demonstrating active mitochondrial DNA transfer.
shortDescription.level8: Polymorphic NUMTs like this demonstrate ongoing organellar-nuclear genome integration, estimated at ~5 events per million years.

funFact.level3: Some people have this DNA and some don't - it's that new!
funFact.level4: DNA is still jumping from mitochondria to chromosomes even today!
funFact.level5: About 5 new NUMTs appear in human lineages every million years - evolution in action!
funFact.level6: Polymorphic NUMTs demonstrate that mitochondrial-nuclear transfer is an ongoing evolutionary process.
funFact.level7: NUMT polymorphism across populations provides insights into human demographic history.
funFact.level8: Population-specific NUMT presence/absence patterns can serve as phylogenetic markers for human migration studies.

shortDescription.level3: A copycat DNA that can confuse scientists trying to solve crimes!
shortDescription.level4: A nuclear copy of mitochondrial DNA that can cause mix-ups in forensic investigations.
shortDescription.level5: A NUMT containing D-loop sequences that can interfere with forensic mitochondrial DNA analysis.
shortDescription.level6: This D-loop NUMT can produce spurious results when standard mtDNA forensic primers are used.
shortDescription.level7: D-loop-containing NUMTs are particularly problematic for forensic mtDNA typing due to primer cross-reactivity.
shortDescription.level8: Forensically problematic NUMTs necessitate careful primer design and sequence verification in mtDNA-based identification.

funFact.level3: This DNA can trick forensic scientists because it looks like mitochondrial DNA!
funFact.level4: Crime labs have to be careful not to accidentally test this instead of real mitochondrial DNA!
funFact.level5: NUMTs have actually caused confusion in some criminal investigations before scientists knew to look for them!
funFact.level6: Several forensic cases have required re-analysis after NUMT co-amplification was discovered.
funFact.level7: NUMT awareness is now standard in forensic mtDNA analysis protocols.
funFact.level8: NUMT contamination led to the development of specialized forensic protocols including whole mtGenome sequencing.

shortDescription.level3: A huge empty stretch of DNA with no genes at all - almost 5 million letters of mystery!
shortDescription.level4: One of the largest gene-free regions in the human genome, spanning almost 5 million base pairs.
shortDescription.level5: A 4.8 Mb gene desert on chromosome 5 - one of the largest in the human genome.
shortDescription.level6: This gene desert contains conserved non-coding elements suggesting regulatory function.
shortDescription.level7: Large gene deserts often harbor enhancers controlling distant developmental genes.
shortDescription.level8: This gene desert contains multiple highly conserved non-coding elements with putative long-range enhancer activity.

funFact.level3: Even though there are no genes here, this DNA is kept almost the same across animals!
funFact.level4: Scientists thought empty DNA would change randomly, but this region stays the same - why?
funFact.level5: Gene deserts often contain hidden control switches for genes that are millions of bases away!
funFact.level6: Conservation in gene deserts suggests important regulatory functions yet to be discovered.
funFact.level7: Many disease-associated variants map to gene deserts, implicating long-range regulatory effects.
funFact.level8: GWAS hits in gene deserts often involve enhancers with complex 3D chromatin interactions to distant promoters.

features.name: PAX6 Regulatory Desert

shortDescription.level3: An empty DNA region that controls how your eyes grow!
shortDescription.level4: A gene-free zone that contains invisible switches controlling eye development.
shortDescription.level5: A gene desert containing enhancers that control PAX6, a master gene for eye development.
shortDescription.level6: This gene desert harbors long-range enhancers for PAX6, mutations in which cause aniridia.
shortDescription.level7: PAX6 enhancer mutations in this desert cause position effect aniridia despite leaving PAX6 intact.
shortDescription.level8: This locus demonstrates how gene desert deletions can cause haploinsufficiency phenotypes through enhancer disruption (position effects).

funFact.level3: Deleting this 'empty' DNA can cause people to be born without irises!
funFact.level4: Even though there are no genes here, losing it can affect your eyes!
funFact.level5: Some people missing this 'empty' region are born with eye problems, proving it's not really empty!
funFact.level6: Aniridia (missing iris) can result from deletions in this 'empty' region, not just PAX6 itself.
funFact.level7: Position effect mutations in gene deserts expanded our understanding of long-range gene regulation.
funFact.level8: PAX6 regulatory mutations provided early evidence for megabase-scale enhancer-promoter interactions in humans.

features.functionKnown: Controls PAX6 expression for eye development

features.name: SHH Regulatory Desert

shortDescription.level3: Empty DNA that tells your body how to grow fingers and toes!
shortDescription.level4: A gene desert containing the famous ZRS enhancer that controls limb development.
shortDescription.level5: This region contains the ZRS (Zone of Polarizing Activity Regulatory Sequence), controlling digit patterning.
shortDescription.level6: The ZRS enhancer in this desert controls SHH expression in limbs; mutations cause polydactyly.
shortDescription.level7: ZRS point mutations cause preaxial polydactyly; the enhancer is ~1 Mb from SHH.
shortDescription.level8: The ZRS demonstrates megabase-scale enhancer-promoter communication, with point mutations causing various polydactyly phenotypes.

funFact.level3: Changes in this 'empty' region can give people extra fingers or toes!
funFact.level4: One tiny change in this region - far from any gene - can make you grow extra fingers!
funFact.level5: The ZRS enhancer is 1 million bases away from the gene it controls - talk about long-distance relationship!
funFact.level6: Ernest Hemingway's famous six-toed cats likely have ZRS mutations.
funFact.level7: ZRS mutations in snakes may have contributed to limb loss during evolution.
funFact.level8: Comparative ZRS analysis in snakes reveals sequence degeneration correlating with limb reduction.

features.functionKnown: Controls limb digit development via SHH

shortDescription.level3: The part of DNA that changed the most since we split from chimps - in our brains!
shortDescription.level4: The fastest-evolving region in human DNA, active during brain development.
shortDescription.level5: The most rapidly evolving sequence in humans, encoding an RNA expressed in developing brain.
shortDescription.level6: HAR1 encodes a non-coding RNA expressed in Cajal-Retzius neurons during cortical development.
shortDescription.level7: HAR1F accumulated 18 human-specific substitutions vs 2 between chimp and chicken over 310MY.
shortDescription.level8: HAR1 shows unprecedented acceleration (18 substitutions vs expected 0.27), with functional implications for neocortical development.

funFact.level3: This tiny bit of DNA changed more in humans than it did between chickens and chimps!
funFact.level4: In 310 million years between chicken and chimp, only 2 changes. In 6 million years in humans, 18 changes!
funFact.level5: HAR1 was virtually frozen for hundreds of millions of years, then suddenly evolved rapidly only in humans!
funFact.level6: The statistical probability of this acceleration by chance is essentially zero.
funFact.level7: HAR1 represents the most extreme example of lineage-specific acceleration in the human genome.
funFact.level8: HAR1 evolution likely involved positive selection, possibly related to brain size or complexity expansion.

features.name: HAR2 (HACNS1)

shortDescription.level3: Super-evolved DNA that might help explain our amazing thumbs!
shortDescription.level4: A rapidly changed region that may have helped humans develop our precise hand grip.
shortDescription.level5: A human-accelerated enhancer active in developing limbs, potentially related to hand dexterity.
shortDescription.level6: HACNS1 gained human-specific enhancer activity in the developing limb, particularly the thumb.
shortDescription.level7: Human-specific substitutions in HACNS1 created novel enhancer activity in the presumptive thumb region.
shortDescription.level8: HACNS1 demonstrates acquisition of novel cis-regulatory activity through accumulated human-specific substitutions.

funFact.level3: This might be part of why humans have such amazing thumbs!
funFact.level4: When scientists put the human version in mice, it lit up where the thumb develops!
funFact.level5: The human HAR2 sequence activates gene expression in developing thumbs - the chimp version doesn't!
funFact.level6: Transgenic assays show human-specific HACNS1 activity in the anterior limb bud.
funFact.level7: HACNS1 exemplifies how non-coding changes can drive morphological evolution.
funFact.level8: HACNS1 is a paradigm for human trait evolution through enhancer modification rather than protein change.

features.functionKnown: May contribute to human hand/thumb development

shortDescription.level3: A region near the gene that helps humans talk and use language!
shortDescription.level4: An accelerated region near FOXP2, the gene important for human speech and language.
shortDescription.level5: A HAR near FOXP2, the gene whose mutation causes speech and language disorders.
shortDescription.level6: Human-accelerated sequences in the FOXP2 region may have contributed to language evolution.
shortDescription.level7: FOXP2 shows two human-specific amino acid changes fixed since the human-Neanderthal split.
shortDescription.level8: The FOXP2 locus contains both coding changes and HARs, representing a complex target of human evolution.

funFact.level3: Mutations in the nearby gene FOXP2 can make it hard to talk!
funFact.level4: The FOXP2 gene is sometimes called 'the language gene' - and this region evolved fast in humans!
funFact.level5: The FOXP2 gene is one of the few genes with human-specific changes that Neanderthals also had!
funFact.level6: Neanderthals shared human FOXP2 variants, suggesting language-related selection predates modern humans.
funFact.level7: FOXP2 underwent a selective sweep ~200,000 years ago in the human lineage.
funFact.level8: Integrating coding and regulatory evolution at FOXP2 remains an active area in human evolution research.

shortDescription.level3: DNA from Neanderthals that helps protect us from germs!
shortDescription.level4: Neanderthal DNA that we kept because it helps our immune system fight infections.
shortDescription.level5: Neanderthal-derived immune genes under positive selection, boosting pathogen defense.
shortDescription.level6: OAS gene cluster variants from Neanderthals show signatures of adaptive introgression.
shortDescription.level7: The OAS1-OAS3 region contains high-frequency Neanderthal haplotypes with enhanced antiviral function.
shortDescription.level8: OAS gene introgression from Neanderthals provides ~2-fold enhanced interferon-induced antiviral response.

funFact.level3: Neanderthal DNA helped our ancestors survive new diseases when they came to Europe!
funFact.level4: About half of Europeans carry this helpful Neanderthal immune DNA!
funFact.level5: Neanderthals had lived in Europe for 200,000+ years and adapted to local diseases - we inherited their protection!
funFact.level6: Adaptive introgression let humans quickly acquire locally-adapted immune variants.
funFact.level7: Multiple toll-like receptor variants from Neanderthals show similar adaptive introgression patterns.
funFact.level8: Immune gene introgression represents the clearest case of adaptive Neanderthal DNA in modern humans.

features.name: Neanderthal Skin/Hair Region

shortDescription.level3: Neanderthal DNA that affected skin and hair to help survive cold, dark Europe!
shortDescription.level4: DNA from Neanderthals that changed skin and hair features for living in Europe's climate.
shortDescription.level5: Introgressed Neanderthal variants affecting skin pigmentation and hair characteristics.
shortDescription.level6: This region contains BNC2 variants from Neanderthals associated with skin pigmentation.
shortDescription.level7: Neanderthal BNC2 haplotypes show frequency clines correlated with latitude in Europeans.
shortDescription.level8: BNC2 introgression demonstrates adaptive phenotypic effects of Neanderthal ancestry on skin saturation and freckling.

funFact.level3: Some of your skin and hair genes might come from Neanderthals!
funFact.level4: Neanderthal DNA affects freckles, skin color, and even how easily you tan!
funFact.level5: 70% of Europeans carry Neanderthal variants affecting skin saturation!
funFact.level6: Neanderthal skin/hair variants helped modern humans adapt to reduced UV in higher latitudes.
funFact.level7: Multiple skin-related loci show evidence of adaptive introgression from Neanderthals.
funFact.level8: Skin pigmentation genes represent the largest category of phenotype-associated Neanderthal variants in Europeans.

features.functionKnown: Affects skin pigmentation and hair characteristics

shortDescription.level3: A place where Neanderthal DNA was removed because it caused problems!
shortDescription.level4: A region where Neanderthal DNA was harmful and got eliminated over time.
shortDescription.level5: A region depleted of Neanderthal ancestry due to negative selection against hybrid incompatibilities.
shortDescription.level6: Introgression deserts mark regions where Neanderthal DNA reduced fitness in hybrids.
shortDescription.level7: This region shows significant depletion of Neanderthal ancestry consistent with hybrid incompatibility.
shortDescription.level8: Neanderthal introgression deserts often contain genes for male fertility and brain development, suggesting reproductive and cognitive incompatibilities.

funFact.level3: Some Neanderthal DNA was bad for human-Neanderthal babies, so it disappeared!
funFact.level4: Neanderthal DNA near genes for thinking and having babies was mostly removed!
funFact.level5: The X chromosome has very little Neanderthal DNA - hybrid males may have been less fertile!
funFact.level6: Introgression deserts suggest partial reproductive isolation between humans and Neanderthals.
funFact.level7: X chromosome depletion follows Haldane's rule predictions for male hybrid dysfunction.
funFact.level8: Introgression desert distribution supports classical hybrid incompatibility theory with X chromosome and spermatogenesis effects.

features.name: Neanderthal COVID Risk Region

shortDescription.level3: Neanderthal DNA that makes COVID-19 more dangerous for some people!
shortDescription.level4: A Neanderthal DNA region that increases the risk of severe COVID-19 illness.
shortDescription.level5: A Neanderthal haplotype associated with approximately 2x increased risk of severe COVID-19.
shortDescription.level6: This introgressed Neanderthal haplotype is the major genetic risk factor for severe COVID-19.
shortDescription.level7: The ~50kb Neanderthal haplotype near LZTFL1 doubles COVID-19 hospitalization risk.
shortDescription.level8: This chr3 Neanderthal haplotype's COVID-19 risk association was among the first GWAS hits for severe disease.

funFact.level3: DNA we got from Neanderthals 50,000 years ago affected COVID-19 in 2020!
funFact.level4: About 16% of Europeans carry this COVID risk DNA from Neanderthals!
funFact.level5: This harmful Neanderthal DNA is common in South Asia (50%) but rare in Africa (0%) and East Asia (4%)!
funFact.level6: The geographic distribution likely reflects different human migration routes and population history.
funFact.level7: This locus demonstrates how archaic introgression can have major effects on modern disease susceptibility.
funFact.level8: This finding highlights how ancestral variants face novel selective pressures from emerging pathogens.

features.functionKnown: Major genetic risk factor for severe COVID-19

shortDescription.level3: Different Neanderthal DNA that actually protects against severe COVID-19!
shortDescription.level4: A protective Neanderthal region - proof that some Neanderthal DNA helps us!
shortDescription.level5: A Neanderthal haplotype at OAS genes that reduces COVID-19 severity by about 22%.
shortDescription.level6: This Neanderthal OAS haplotype provides protection against severe COVID-19 outcomes.
shortDescription.level7: The protective effect involves enhanced OAS1 enzyme activity against SARS-CoV-2.
shortDescription.level8: This protective haplotype contains a splice variant producing a more active OAS1 isoform against coronaviruses.

funFact.level3: Some Neanderthal DNA makes COVID worse, but this DNA makes it better!
funFact.level4: About half of people outside Africa carry this helpful Neanderthal COVID protection!
funFact.level5: The same Neanderthals gave us both COVID risk AND COVID protection - in different DNA regions!
funFact.level6: Neanderthal introgression's health effects are complex - both harmful and beneficial variants exist.
funFact.level7: The opposing COVID effects of different Neanderthal haplotypes illustrate introgression's complexity.
funFact.level8: These contrasting COVID associations demonstrate context-dependent effects of archaic introgression on modern phenotypes.

shortDescription.level3: Neanderthal DNA that makes some people feel more pain!
shortDescription.level4: A Neanderthal gene variant that affects how sensitive people are to pain.
shortDescription.level5: A Neanderthal SCN9A variant associated with increased pain sensitivity in carriers.
shortDescription.level6: The Neanderthal SCN9A haplotype affects sodium channel function and pain perception.
shortDescription.level7: Neanderthal SCN9A variants lower the activation threshold for pain-sensing neurons.
shortDescription.level8: The introgressed SCN9A variants alter Nav1.7 channel gating, increasing nociceptor excitability.

funFact.level3: Some people feel more pain because of DNA they got from Neanderthals!
funFact.level4: About 0.4% of British people carry this Neanderthal pain gene!
funFact.level5: Neanderthals may have been more pain-sensitive than modern humans!
funFact.level6: This represents a rare case of Neanderthal DNA having detrimental phenotypic effects.
funFact.level7: The pain-related Neanderthal haplotype is at low frequency, consistent with negative selection.
funFact.level8: Low frequency of this haplotype suggests ongoing purifying selection against the pain-sensitizing alleles.

shortDescription.level3: The spot where two ape chromosomes stuck together to make human chromosome 2!
shortDescription.level4: Where two separate chromosomes from our ape ancestors fused together millions of years ago.
shortDescription.level5: The fusion point of ancestral chromosomes 2A and 2B, explaining why humans have 46 chromosomes while great apes have 48.
shortDescription.level6: Telomere-to-telomere fusion site containing remnant telomeric sequences, proving human chromosome 2 arose from fusion.
shortDescription.level7: Contains head-to-head telomeric repeats (TTAGGG)n and a vestigial centromere, definitively establishing the fusion origin.
shortDescription.level8: The 2q13-2q14.1 fusion site contains degenerate telomeric arrays in head-to-head orientation plus an inactive centromere at 2q21, providing unequivocal evidence of chromosomal fusion.

funFact.level3: This is the proof that humans evolved from apes - you can see where two chromosomes stuck together!
funFact.level4: Great apes like chimps have 48 chromosomes, we have 46. This fusion is why!
funFact.level5: You can still see the old telomeres (chromosome end caps) stuck in the middle of chromosome 2!
funFact.level6: The vestigial telomeres and inactive centromere are 'smoking gun' evidence for human-ape common ancestry.
funFact.level7: This fusion event occurred ~4-5 million years ago in the human lineage after divergence from chimpanzees.
funFact.level8: The fusion junction contains ~800 degenerate TTAGGG repeats in head-to-head arrangement, plus a recognizable but inactivated ancestral centromere.

shortDescription.level3: An old chromosome center that doesn't work anymore!
shortDescription.level4: The leftover centromere from one of the ape chromosomes that fused to make human chromosome 2.
shortDescription.level5: An inactive centromere from ancestral chromosome 2B, silenced after the fusion event.
shortDescription.level6: Vestigial alphoid sequences from the ancestral 2B centromere, now epigenetically silenced.
shortDescription.level7: Contains degraded alpha satellite arrays lacking CENP-A deposition, rendering it non-functional.
shortDescription.level8: The 2q21 vestigial centromere retains recognizable alphoid sequences but lacks centromeric chromatin marks (CENP-A, H3K4me2).

funFact.level3: Every chromosome needs a center (centromere) - but chromosome 2 has TWO, and one is broken!
funFact.level4: When the chromosomes fused, one centromere had to be turned off or the chromosome wouldn't work!
funFact.level5: Having two active centromeres would cause the chromosome to be torn apart during cell division!
funFact.level6: Dicentric chromosomes are unstable; one centromere had to be inactivated for the fusion to succeed.
funFact.level7: Centromere inactivation likely occurred through epigenetic silencing rather than sequence deletion.
funFact.level8: The rapid centromere inactivation following fusion demonstrates the genome's ability to epigenetically resolve dicentric instability.

shortDescription.level3: DNA from mysterious ancient humans called Denisovans that helps our immune system!
shortDescription.level4: Immune genes inherited from Denisovans, an ancient human species known only from a few bones.
shortDescription.level5: HLA variants inherited from Denisovans that provide enhanced immune diversity and pathogen resistance.
shortDescription.level6: Denisovan-derived HLA haplotypes contributing to adaptive immunity in Asian and Oceanian populations.
shortDescription.level7: HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C alleles introgressed from Denisovans showing evidence of positive selection.
shortDescription.level8: Archaic HLA introgression from Denisovans contributes >50% of HLA-B alleles in some Melanesian populations.

funFact.level3: We only know Denisovans from a finger bone and teeth, but their DNA lives on in billions of people!
funFact.level4: Denisovans were discovered in 2010 from DNA in a tiny finger bone found in a Siberian cave!
funFact.level5: Up to 6% of Melanesian and Aboriginal Australian DNA comes from Denisovans!
funFact.level6: Denisovan DNA is most common in people from Papua New Guinea and Australia.
funFact.level7: Multiple Denisovan introgression events may have occurred at different times and locations.
funFact.level8: Population genetics suggests at least two distinct Denisovan admixture events into different modern human populations.

shortDescription.level3: Denisovan DNA that helps Tibetans breathe at super high mountains!
shortDescription.level4: A gene from Denisovans that helps Tibetan people survive at high altitudes where there's less oxygen.
shortDescription.level5: The EPAS1 gene variant from Denisovans that allows Tibetans to thrive at altitudes above 4,000 meters.
shortDescription.level6: Denisovan-derived EPAS1 haplotype providing blunted hypoxic response and high-altitude adaptation.
shortDescription.level7: The EPAS1 Tibetan haplotype shows highest archaic match to Denisovans, demonstrating adaptive introgression for altitude.
shortDescription.level8: EPAS1 introgression from Denisovans represents one of the clearest examples of adaptive archaic alleles in modern humans.

funFact.level3: Without this Denisovan DNA, Tibetans couldn't live on their super-high plateau!
funFact.level4: This gene helps Tibetans survive where others get mountain sickness!
funFact.level5: 87% of Tibetans carry this Denisovan variant, but it's rare everywhere else!
funFact.level6: This is the strongest signal of adaptive introgression in humans - incredibly rare except in Tibet.
funFact.level7: The EPAS1 introgression allowed rapid high-altitude adaptation without waiting for new mutations.
funFact.level8: EPAS1 adaptive introgression shows how archaic DNA enabled human colonization of extreme environments.

shortDescription.level3: Denisovan DNA that helps some people eat lots of fat without getting sick!
shortDescription.level4: A gene variant from Denisovans that helps Inuit people digest their traditional high-fat diet.
shortDescription.level5: FADS gene variants from Denisovans that improve omega-3 fatty acid metabolism.
shortDescription.level6: Denisovan-derived FADS cluster variants selected in populations with marine-based diets.
shortDescription.level7: Introgressed FADS haplotypes show strong selection signals in Greenlandic Inuit and other Arctic populations.
shortDescription.level8: FADS introgression demonstrates how archaic alleles facilitated metabolic adaptation to Arctic diets rich in marine lipids.

funFact.level3: Inuit people can eat whale blubber and seal fat thanks to ancient DNA!
funFact.level4: Arctic peoples adapted to eating almost nothing but fatty meat and fish!
funFact.level5: These variants help convert omega fatty acids, crucial for a diet of seals and whales!
funFact.level6: Selection for these variants is among the strongest signals in the human genome.
funFact.level7: Multiple archaic introgression events contributed to fatty acid metabolism adaptation.
funFact.level8: FADS adaptive introgression illustrates the complex interplay between archaic admixture, diet, and natural selection.

shortDescription.level3: Special Denisovan DNA only found in people from certain Indonesian islands!
shortDescription.level4: Unique Denisovan ancestry found in people from the Philippines and Indonesia.
shortDescription.level5: A distinct Denisovan population's DNA found only in Philippine Negrito and some Indonesian groups.
shortDescription.level6: Evidence for a 'southern Denisovan' population distinct from the Siberian Denisovan genome.
shortDescription.level7: Philippine Ayta Magbukon carry highest levels of Denisovan ancestry (~5%) from a distinct source population.
shortDescription.level8: Population genetics reveals multiple Denisovan lineages, with 'Denisovan 2' contributing specifically to Philippine/Indonesian populations.

funFact.level3: Some island peoples have MORE Denisovan DNA than Neanderthal DNA!
funFact.level4: The Ayta Magbukon people of the Philippines have the most Denisovan DNA of anyone!
funFact.level5: There were probably multiple groups of Denisovans across Asia - we've only found bones from one!
funFact.level6: Different island populations met different Denisovan groups in Southeast Asia.
funFact.level7: The 'southern Denisovan' was likely better adapted to tropical environments than Siberian Denisovans.
funFact.level8: Multiple Denisovan introgression waves suggest archaic hominins were widespread across Asia and Oceania.

shortDescription.level3: Skin and hair genes from both Neanderthals and Denisovans!
shortDescription.level4: Keratin genes for skin and hair that we inherited from multiple ancient human species.
shortDescription.level5: Keratin gene cluster with both Neanderthal and Denisovan variants affecting hair and skin structure.
shortDescription.level6: KRT gene cluster variants from archaic humans under positive selection in Eurasian populations.
shortDescription.level7: Both Neanderthal and Denisovan haplotypes at keratin loci show elevated frequencies outside Africa.
shortDescription.level8: Keratin gene cluster archaic introgression demonstrates convergent selection for integumentary adaptation to non-African environments.

funFact.level3: Your hair and skin might be partly designed by Neanderthals AND Denisovans!
funFact.level4: Ancient humans who lived in cold Europe had thicker skin and different hair - and shared it with us!
funFact.level5: Both Neanderthals and Denisovans contributed to our skin and hair, helping ancestors survive new climates!
funFact.level6: Keratin variants from archaic humans may have helped modern humans adapt to UV and climate.
funFact.level7: Archaic keratin introgression likely facilitated rapid adaptation during the out-of-Africa expansion.
funFact.level8: The convergent selection on archaic keratin haplotypes illustrates the fitness advantage of standing archaic variation.

shortDescription.level3: Germ-fighting genes from ancient humans that help us today!
shortDescription.level4: Immune receptor genes from Neanderthals and Denisovans that help detect infections.
shortDescription.level5: Toll-like receptor variants from archaic humans that enhance detection of bacteria and viruses.
shortDescription.level6: TLR1, TLR6, and TLR10 haplotypes introgressed from Neanderthals with enhanced pathogen recognition.
shortDescription.level7: Archaic TLR haplotypes at ~50% frequency in Eurasians show evidence of adaptive introgression.
shortDescription.level8: TLR cluster introgression demonstrates how archaic alleles pre-adapted to local pathogens provided selective advantages.

funFact.level3: Neanderthals fought European germs for 200,000 years and gave us their best defenses!
funFact.level4: About half of all Europeans carry Neanderthal immune genes at these locations!
funFact.level5: These archaic immune variants were so useful that they spread through human populations rapidly!
funFact.level6: The rapid spread of these variants demonstrates strong positive selection.
funFact.level7: TLR introgression may have come with tradeoffs - some variants increase allergy risk.
funFact.level8: Archaic TLR introgression exemplifies the complex fitness effects of adaptive archaic alleles.

shortDescription.level3: A gene that, when broken, makes breast and ovarian cancer much more likely.
shortDescription.level4: An important DNA repair gene - mutations greatly increase cancer risk in women.
shortDescription.level5: A tumor suppressor gene whose mutations confer high lifetime risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA1 encodes a DNA repair protein; loss-of-function mutations cause hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA1 mutations confer ~70% lifetime breast cancer risk and ~40% ovarian cancer risk.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1 participates in homologous recombination repair; pathogenic variants cause HBOC syndrome with characteristic tumor spectrum.

funFact.level3: Angelina Jolie has a BRCA1 mutation - she told everyone to raise awareness!
funFact.level4: Some BRCA1 mutations are more common in certain groups, like Ashkenazi Jews.
funFact.level5: BRCA1 testing revolutionized cancer prevention - now people can take action before cancer develops!
funFact.level6: BRCA1 founder mutations occur in ~2% of Ashkenazi Jewish individuals.
funFact.level7: PARP inhibitors now specifically target BRCA-mutant cancers through synthetic lethality.
funFact.level8: BRCA1 haploinsufficiency combined with PARP inhibition creates synthetic lethality in tumor cells.

shortDescription.level3: A gene that, when both copies are broken, causes a disease that makes breathing hard.
shortDescription.level4: The gene for cystic fibrosis - you need two broken copies to get the disease.
shortDescription.level5: The chloride channel gene whose mutations cause cystic fibrosis, the most common lethal genetic disease in Caucasians.
shortDescription.level6: CFTR encodes a chloride channel; homozygous loss-of-function causes cystic fibrosis affecting lungs and pancreas.
shortDescription.level7: The F508 mutation accounts for ~70% of CF alleles worldwide with clear founder effect in Europeans.
shortDescription.level8: CFTR mutations cause defective chloride transport leading to viscous secretions, chronic infection, and progressive organ damage.

funFact.level3: Being a carrier of ONE broken copy might have protected people from cholera!
funFact.level4: About 1 in 25 Caucasians carries a CF mutation but doesn't have the disease!
funFact.level5: CF carrier advantage against cholera/typhoid may explain why the mutation is so common!
funFact.level6: The heterozygote advantage hypothesis for CFTR is similar to sickle cell and malaria.
funFact.level7: New CFTR modulators like ivacaftor can restore function to some mutant proteins.
funFact.level8: CFTR modulator therapy represents a triumph of molecular genetics-to-treatment translation.

features.name: HTT Gene (Huntingtin)

shortDescription.level3: A gene where extra DNA repeats cause a brain disease later in life.
shortDescription.level4: The gene for Huntington's disease - too many CAG repeats cause neurons to die.
shortDescription.level5: A gene with a CAG trinucleotide repeat; expansion beyond 36 repeats causes Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level6: HTT CAG expansion causes toxic polyglutamine aggregation leading to striatal neurodegeneration.
shortDescription.level7: Huntington's shows anticipation - repeat length tends to increase when passed from father to child.
shortDescription.level8: HTT aggregation causes selective medium spiny neuron death through disrupted proteostasis and transcriptional dysregulation.

funFact.level3: Woody Guthrie, the famous folk singer, had Huntington's disease.
funFact.level4: The more CAG repeats you have, the younger you get sick - it's very predictable!
funFact.level5: Huntington's was one of the first genes mapped using linkage analysis in families.
funFact.level6: HD is one of few diseases where genetic test almost perfectly predicts who will develop disease.
funFact.level7: Gene silencing approaches are in clinical trials to treat Huntington's disease.
funFact.level8: Allele-selective HTT lowering strategies aim to reduce mutant huntingtin while preserving wild-type function.

features.functionKnown: Unknown normal function; aggregation causes disease

shortDescription.level3: The biggest gene in humans! When broken, boys' muscles get weaker and weaker.
shortDescription.level4: The largest human gene - mutations cause Duchenne muscular dystrophy in boys.
shortDescription.level5: The largest human gene (2.2 Mb), whose mutations cause Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies.
shortDescription.level6: DMD encodes dystrophin, a structural protein linking the cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix in muscle.
shortDescription.level7: Frame-shifting DMD mutations cause severe Duchenne MD; in-frame deletions cause milder Becker MD.
shortDescription.level8: Dystrophin absence leads to sarcolemmal instability, calcium influx, and progressive myofiber necrosis with fibrofatty replacement.

funFact.level3: This gene is SO big that it takes 16 HOURS to read from start to finish!
funFact.level4: The DMD gene has 79 exons - most genes have only a few!
funFact.level5: Because it's on the X chromosome, boys get the disease but girls are usually just carriers.
funFact.level6: DMD's huge size (~2.2 Mb) makes it a large mutational target with high de novo mutation rate.
funFact.level7: Exon-skipping antisense oligonucleotides are FDA-approved for specific DMD mutations.
funFact.level8: Dystrophin's large size enables exon-skipping approaches, as internally deleted proteins can retain function.

shortDescription.level3: A gene where too many repeats cause learning difficulties and autism-like features.
shortDescription.level4: The gene for Fragile X syndrome - the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.
shortDescription.level5: A CGG repeat expansion disorder; the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and autism.
shortDescription.level6: FMR1 CGG expansion causes transcriptional silencing and loss of FMRP, essential for synaptic plasticity.
shortDescription.level7: Full mutations (>200 CGG) cause hypermethylation and gene silencing; premutations cause distinct disorders.
shortDescription.level8: FMRP regulates mRNA transport and local translation at synapses; its loss disrupts metabotropic glutamate receptor signaling.

funFact.level3: The gene got its name because the X chromosome looks 'fragile' or broken at that spot!
funFact.level4: Premutation carriers (55-200 repeats) can develop different problems than full mutations!
funFact.level5: Fragile X premutation carriers may develop tremor and balance problems later in life!
funFact.level6: Premutation carriers (~1/150 females) are at risk for FXTAS and premature ovarian insufficiency.
funFact.level7: The premutation paradox: some carriers show RNA-mediated toxicity while others are phenotypically normal.
funFact.level8: FMR1 premutation causes toxic gain-of-function through CGG RNA-mediated mechanisms distinct from full mutation loss-of-function.

shortDescription.level3: A gene that helps break down a part of protein - when broken, a special diet is needed!
shortDescription.level4: The gene for phenylketonuria - babies are tested at birth so they can start a special diet.
shortDescription.level5: The phenylalanine hydroxylase gene; mutations cause PKU, treatable with dietary restriction.
shortDescription.level6: PAH deficiency causes phenylalanine accumulation; dietary treatment prevents intellectual disability.
shortDescription.level7: PKU was the first inborn error of metabolism treated by dietary modification and screened at birth.
shortDescription.level8: PAH deficiency demonstrates the power of early detection through newborn screening and metabolic pathway intervention.

funFact.level3: Every baby born in the US gets tested for PKU with a tiny blood test!
funFact.level4: PKU babies who eat a special low-protein diet grow up totally healthy!
funFact.level5: Before newborn screening, PKU caused severe intellectual disability. Now it's completely preventable!
funFact.level6: PKU treatment is a triumph of biochemical genetics - understanding the pathway enabled rational therapy.
funFact.level7: The aspartame warning 'contains phenylalanine' is specifically for people with PKU.
funFact.level8: PKU exemplifies the paradigm shift from untreatable genetic disease to manageable metabolic condition.

shortDescription.level3: A gene where one broken copy fights malaria, but two cause sickle cell disease.
shortDescription.level4: The beta-globin gene - sickle cell trait protects against malaria but the disease is serious.
shortDescription.level5: A classic example of balancing selection: heterozygotes resist malaria, homozygotes have sickle cell disease.
shortDescription.level6: HBB E6V mutation provides malaria resistance in heterozygotes but causes hemoglobinopathy in homozygotes.
shortDescription.level7: Sickle cell disease demonstrates heterozygote advantage maintaining deleterious alleles in populations.
shortDescription.level8: The HBB sickle allele is a textbook example of balanced polymorphism driven by Plasmodium falciparum selection.

funFact.level3: Having ONE copy of the sickle gene actually PROTECTS you from malaria!
funFact.level4: The sickle cell mutation is common in Africa because malaria is common there!
funFact.level5: This is a famous example of 'heterozygote advantage' - carriers are better off than either homozygote!
funFact.level6: The sickle allele reaches ~15% frequency in some malaria-endemic regions.
funFact.level7: Gene therapy and gene editing approaches are now curing sickle cell disease.
funFact.level8: CRISPR-based therapies reactivating fetal hemoglobin represent revolutionary treatment for sickle cell disease.

shortDescription.level3: A gene region that might help some people live past 100 years old!
shortDescription.level4: The FOXO3 gene - variants here are found more often in people who live past 100.
shortDescription.level5: A FOXO3 region containing variants significantly associated with exceptional longevity across populations.
shortDescription.level6: FOXO3 variants show consistent association with longevity in multiple independent centenarian studies.
shortDescription.level7: FOXO3 regulates stress resistance, metabolism, and autophagy - pathways central to aging biology.
shortDescription.level8: FOXO3 longevity associations replicate across ethnic groups, suggesting fundamental importance in human aging.

funFact.level3: The same gene that helps worms and flies live longer also helps humans live longer!
funFact.level4: FOXO3 longevity variants are found in centenarians from Japan, Germany, Italy, and America!
funFact.level5: This is one of very few genes consistently linked to extreme longevity across different populations.
funFact.level6: FOXO proteins are evolutionarily conserved regulators of lifespan from worms to humans.
funFact.level7: Modulating FOXO activity extends lifespan in model organisms - a potential therapeutic target.
funFact.level8: FOXO3 represents a rare validated human longevity gene with clear mechanistic links to aging biology.

shortDescription.level3: A piece of DNA that chimps have but humans lost - it might be why we're different!
shortDescription.level4: An enhancer that was deleted in humans but exists in all other apes.
shortDescription.level5: A regulatory element deleted in humans that controls androgen receptor expression in developing tissues.
shortDescription.level6: A human-specific deletion of an AR enhancer, associated with loss of penile spines and increased brain size.
shortDescription.level7: This deletion removes an androgen-responsive enhancer, potentially affecting both genital and brain development.
