shortDescription.level8: The hCONDEL at this locus eliminates AR-dependent enhancer activity in developing external genitalia and frontal cortex.

funFact.level3: Some scientists think this deletion helped human brains get bigger!
funFact.level4: Unlike chimps and gorillas, humans don't have penile spines - this gene explains why!
funFact.level5: This deletion may have contributed to longer mating times in humans compared to chimps!
funFact.level6: Human-specific gene losses can be as important as gains for our unique traits.
funFact.level7: This deletion demonstrates that human evolution involved loss of features, not just gains.
funFact.level8: Phenotypic losses through cis-regulatory deletions represent an underappreciated mechanism of human trait evolution.

shortDescription.level3: Genes that copied themselves only in humans and might have made our brains special!
shortDescription.level4: A gene that humans copied multiple times, which may have helped our brains develop more connections.
shortDescription.level5: Human-specific SRGAP2 duplications that affect brain neuron density and spine development.
shortDescription.level6: SRGAP2B/C are human-specific partial duplications that inhibit ancestral SRGAP2A function in developing brain.
shortDescription.level7: SRGAP2C duplication ~2.4 MYA coincides with brain expansion and may increase dendritic spine density.
shortDescription.level8: SRGAP2 paralogs demonstrate how gene duplication and neofunctionalization contributed to human brain evolution.

funFact.level3: These gene copies only exist in humans - not in chimps or any other animal!
funFact.level4: The duplications happened around when human brains started getting bigger!
funFact.level5: These copies slow down neuron development, which paradoxically makes more brain connections!
funFact.level6: Slower synapse maturation may allow for more complex brain wiring in humans.
funFact.level7: SRGAP2 duplications exemplify how human-specific segmental duplications shaped brain evolution.
funFact.level8: The SRGAP2C paralog acts as a dominant negative, prolonging spine maturation and increasing density.

shortDescription.level3: Special genes only humans have that might explain why our brains are so big!
shortDescription.level4: Genes found only in humans that tell brain stem cells to keep dividing and make bigger brains.
shortDescription.level5: Human-specific NOTCH2NL genes that increase neural progenitor proliferation and brain size.
shortDescription.level6: NOTCH2NL genes arose ~3-4 MYA through segmental duplication and promote cortical expansion.
shortDescription.level7: NOTCH2NL amplifies Notch signaling in neural progenitors, delaying differentiation and expanding the progenitor pool.
shortDescription.level8: NOTCH2NL paralogs promote indirect neurogenesis by maintaining radial glial identity, contributing to human cortical expansion.

funFact.level3: These genes tell brain cells 'keep growing!' - that's why human brains are so big!
funFact.level4: Deletions in this region can cause microcephaly, and duplications can cause macrocephaly!
funFact.level5: These are some of the newest genes in the human genome - they appeared only 3-4 million years ago!
funFact.level6: NOTCH2NL provides direct mechanistic link between human-specific genes and brain size.
funFact.level7: 1q21.1 CNVs involving NOTCH2NL cause neurodevelopmental disorders with altered head size.
funFact.level8: NOTCH2NL discovery provides functional validation for human-specific gene duplications in brain evolution.

shortDescription.level3: A jaw muscle gene that broke in humans - maybe to make room for bigger brains!
shortDescription.level4: A muscle gene that stopped working in humans ~2.4 million years ago.
shortDescription.level5: A myosin gene inactivated ~2.4 MYA, coinciding with brain expansion in human ancestors.
shortDescription.level6: MYH16 pseudogenization may have relaxed constraints on skull size, facilitating encephalization.
shortDescription.level7: The MYH16 inactivating mutation dates to ~2.4 MYA, correlating with reduced masticatory apparatus in Homo.
shortDescription.level8: While correlative, MYH16 inactivation represents a compelling case of gene loss contributing to human morphological evolution.

funFact.level3: Chimps have super strong jaw muscles. We traded strong jaws for bigger brains!
funFact.level4: The timing of this gene breaking matches exactly when human skulls started changing!
funFact.level5: This is one of the only examples where a broken gene might have made humans better!
funFact.level6: Gene loss can be adaptive - sometimes breaking things makes room for new developments.
funFact.level7: The MYH16 case illustrates that gene loss, not just gain, shapes human evolution.
funFact.level8: Phenotypic trade-offs through gene inactivation may have facilitated human cranial evolution.
